name: c.i. disperse blue 3

Incorporating the effects of various functional groups: - The two amide groups are expected to increase the melting point due to their potential to form hydrogen bonds and because of the rigidity they add to the structure. Each amide might contribute around +20-30°C. - The amino group could also increase the melting point by a similar amount due to hydrogen bonding, adding another +20-30°C. - The ether linkage (–O–) would have a more moderate effect, potentially increasing the melting point by about +5-10°C since it's also capable of dipole-dipole interactions but is more flexible than amide groups. - The overall molecule is quite large and planar, which tends to increase the melting point because of the larger surface area for van der Waals interactions, adding perhaps an additional +10-20°C. This gives us an estimate increase of about +75 to +110°C over the naphthalene base.

Each amide can increase the melting point due to the possibility of hydrogen bonding and rigid structure (+40°C each). The additional fused aromatic rings provide further rigidity and increase the surface area for van der Waals interactions, hence we might estimate an increase of (+30°C for fused rings). However, these changes do not simply add up due to the complexity of intermolecular forces in such a large molecule; they interact in a non-linear manner.
